text: - Please join us in this video

as we walk through the steps
to add an ExpressLink module

to an AWS IoT console
and show real time data.
And now over to our technical expert Dan.
- [Daniel] In order to add the thing name

and the certificate to the
thing in your AWS account,
you first need to get the thing name

and the certificate from
the ExpressLink module.
In order to do that,

you can issue an AT
+CONT? ThingName command
here in the serial interface.
In the Arduino IDE,
you can simply type it in and retrieve it.
Here you should copy it for use later.
Next, for the certificate you can issue
an AT +CONT? Certificate command,
and here you can copy the output
and create a file with the extension .pem.
Now, if we move to the AWS IoT console,

and scroll down to manage,
all devices, things.
Click create things.
You'll be creating a single thing.

And the thing name should
correspond to the thing name

that you retrieved from
the ExpressLink module.
Copy that in that field.
Hit next.
Then choose use my certificate,

and also choose CA is not
registered with AWS IoT.
Now choose the file that you created
with the .pem extension,
and click next.

Finally, you have to attach
a policy to the certificate.

I've already created
IoTDevPolicy, but if you haven't,
you can create a policy with this button.
The IoTDevPolicy is fairly simple.

It allows actions and resources
across just wild cards.

From there, simply create
thing by clicking create thing.
Now you can see it in your console.
To see your data in the IoT console,
simply navigate to AWS IoT.
Then under test, MQTT test client.
In the MQTT test client page,

subscribe to the topic that
you used to send your data.
In this case, dt/sensor/# will retrieve
all the messages published on that topic.
Here, you can see the weather station data
that we've sent from our weather station

being sent every minute
into the MQTT broker.
- Thanks Dan, for showing us

how we can use AWS
ExpressLink with such ease.
